[b]I booted up Marvel Rivals hoping to swing into some web-shooting fun or hurl fireballs as my favorite hero, but after a quick round, I had to admit: this one’s just not my cup of tea. The game tries hard to mix flashy superpowers with shooter mechanics, but the mash-up ends up feeling more like a flashy costume party than a clash of Titans.

The visuals are colorful and punchy, it’s like playing inside a comic book that exploded in neon confetti. Powers fly, environments flicker, and chaos reigns as characters bounce, blast, and zoom across the map. If I were into over-the-top action and flashy combos, I’d get a kick out of it. Some matches even felt fun enough to make me forget my usual taste in steady-paced shooters.

But here’s the deal: the third-person perspective, the constant frenzy, and the power-combo overload make aiming feel more like “spray and pray, with flair.” For someone who prefers grounded gunplay, tactical decisions, or a good ol’ fashioned headshot, Marvel Rivals feels a bit too much like a fireworks show. I ended up dodging abilities more than aiming at enemies, and that’s a sign I’m not built for this kind of hero chaos.

In short: Marvel Rivals might be the perfect match for fans of bombastic, chaotic hero shooters, but for me, it’s a bit like wearing a superhero costume to a chess match. Fun to look at, but not really dressed for the game.[/b]

Marvel Rivals is a refreshing take on the hero shooter formula. It captures that energetic, team-focused chaos we used to love in other games, but adds a polish and momentum that makes it stand out. Every match feels explosive, cinematic, and fast-paced, with just enough chaos to be thrilling without becoming a mess. It’s one of those games where every round tells its own little story, and you walk away with highlight moments whether you win or lose.

One of the biggest things it gets right is giving players access to everything from the start. You don’t have to grind for weeks just to try a new character. You’re free to experiment with different playstyles, combos, and strategies right away. Skins are where the monetization comes in, and thankfully, they’re handled well — stylish, detailed, and actually fun to unlock or buy. It feels like you're rewarded for playing, not punished for not spending. It’s a breath of fresh air in a genre that’s gotten way too greedy.

Now, it’s not a perfect 10. Balance is still a work in progress, and it shows. Some characters definitely feel overtuned, and when one or two picks start dominating every match, the fun can take a hit. But the developers seem to know this — constant patch notes, buffs, and nerfs are a regular thing. It’s the kind of game you know is being watched and tweaked constantly. While that means no balance is ever permanent, it also means the game evolves, and that keeps things interesting.

The best part? The devs aren't holding back on content. We're getting new skins, events, and even new heroes nearly every month. Some cosmetics are just cosmetic, but others feel like love letters to fans — alternate looks, seasonal designs, and even crossover-style vibes that keep things fresh. It feels alive, like something that's meant to grow with the player base, not just sit still. You log in and there’s always something new to check out — whether it’s a visual update, a gameplay patch, or a new mode in rotation.

The core gameplay is fun. Teamfights feel dynamic, movement is smooth, and there's just enough tactical depth to reward coordination without making solo players feel useless. Whether you like fast engagements or support-style roles, the game gives you room to play your way. There’s a real sense of momentum in each round, and pulling off a win with a good team feels genuinely satisfying. Maps are detailed, destructible in spots, and designed to keep the action flowing.

But if there’s one thing that ruins it, it’s the players. The toxic ones, at least. Whether it’s someone trash-talking in voice chat or deliberately throwing the match because things didn’t go their way, bad behavior can drag down an otherwise great experience. No matter how well the game plays, the vibe can shift fast when teamwork falls apart. Marvel Rivals has the mechanics and design to be something truly long-lasting — but like every online game, its biggest challenge isn’t just balance or content. It’s us.

Like many competitive games, Marvel Rivals is fun—right up until you start taking it seriously. The community experience quickly falls apart, largely because the open-queue system is fundamentally flawed. It allows team compositions that simply don’t work, and the player-ranking system becomes unreliable when you’re expected to perform equally across all roles, among other issues. Most players clearly prefer DPS, so you end up rolling the dice on team balance before the match even starts.

Open queue does have its upsides: it felt fresh at first, it adds variety, and queue times are shorter. But these benefits come at a cost. In an ideal world, this system could be great. In reality—when you factor in immature, self-important players, or people who don’t have the time to play all roles and would prefer to specialize—the experience falls apart.

It also feels like the developers tried to compensate by giving each role a few overly simplified but overly reliable heroes. I’m not a fan of this direction. It lowers the skill floor for accessibility, which is fine on paper, but the advantages only really shine when you have a team willing to adapt. And based on my experience, that’s not something you can consistently rely on. It should be the game’s job to minimize the number of “bad matches,” not the community’s—and right now, the game is failing at that.

The frustrating part is that Marvel Rivals launched with a lot of genuinely smart improvements to the hero-shooter formula and a surprisingly large amount of content. But at this point, I think the devs need to slow down and focus on fixing the underlying systems instead of constantly adding new heroes, new maps, and balance changes. It’s getting harder to keep up with, meanwhile the core issues remain untouched. Quickplay being a pretty horrible game mode to learn new heroes in it's current state is one that contributes to that.

And then there’s the optimization. The game looks great—especially for a competitive title—but it should run better on new, modern hardware without having to drop everything to low in conjunction with upscaling to get a competitively playable experience. I don’t mind upscaling on its own (it helps a lot for minimal cost), but this game is really pushing the limits of poor optimization. It still needs work in that department.

First of all, this is a horrible game. I’d like to say I have a love–hate relationship with it, but frankly, it’s just hate. To this day, I cannot come up with a single compelling reason to play it. I genuinely tried to think of anything positive and came up with nothing. The game is not fun, and it does not feel satisfying in any way.

One of its biggest issues is the extreme inconsistency between matches. Losing makes you feel miserable, not only because of crazily unbalanced matchmaking but also because the game is poorly optimised. It’s also painfully obvious that the developers prioritise quantity over quality. Their constant stream of updates feels directionless and sloppy. I would much rather play a game with a solid, stable foundation than one that fundamentally changes every few months. If they stopped updating this game, I’m convinced the entire player base would disappear, unlike older classics such as Team Fortress 2. The lack of cohesive gameplay design is obvious even in basic elements like movement abilities being bound to different keys for absolutely no reason, which is by no means user-friendly. 

That said, I have to give the developers some credit: they have somehow created the perfect formula for an intensely addictive game. Most of that comes from the inevitable 50/50 win–loss ratio the game tries to shove down your throat. The issue is that wins often feel meaningless because they are too easy, while losses can feel devastating. You feel powerless while being stuck with bot-like teammates facing veteran opponents. The only real positives I can acknowledge are the art style and a handful of unique abilities. And of course, they have absolutely mastered the art of monetisation. They know sex sells, so nearly every skin is designed as a thirst trap, men and women alike. It’s effective but incredibly scummy. 

You might then ask: “If you hate it so much, why do you have so many hours in it?”, and the answer is simple: it’s the most common game my friends and I can play together. Although playing together is far from quality time, most of it is spent complaining and raging. Maybe 5% of matches, we actually have a pleasant conversation alongside the chaos. And honestly, I’d much rather play Overwatch, simply because it's more my cup of tea and is a more polished game by all means. Marvel Rivals feels like a worse, broken version of Overwatch, and I even think some people only started playing it out of spite toward Overwatch 2. As someone who is only a below-average Marvel fan, even I can say this is a poorly made title wrapped in a Marvel skin. Strip away the Marvel branding, and nobody would be playing this garbage.

As a final note, Galacta’s annoying voice is the cherry on top of this already unbearable heap of trash. At the end of the day, when I’m unsure what to play, Marvel Rivals serves as a reminder and a perfect motivator to play absolutely anything else.

Hello to whoever is reading this.

In short, the idea of the game is good overall, but the execution is honestly the worst I’ve seen in years. The gameplay feels wonky, and I often get killed by completely random-looking shots. I understand it’s a third-person game, so certain angles will favor one side more, but that doesn’t mean the hit register shouldn’t work. Hitboxes feel inconsistent and all over the place.

The worst part for me is the death cam. If you’re not going to fix it, then just remove it. You can’t learn anything from it because it shows the wrong information. The enemy could be aiming at your head, but the death cam will show them grazing your toes. It’s misleading and makes it impossible to understand how you actually died.

Matchmaking is also just bad. In Quickplay, new players join and get stomped, older players want to relax and not sweat, and then you have sweats who jump in and treat every match like it’s a tournament. The mode ends up being a mix where nobody is getting what they actually want—new players get crushed, casuals get stressed, and sweats get bored because the lobby is inconsistent.

Maybe I’m nostalgic, but it really feels like only the top 1%—sweats, pros, streamers—are being listened to. Casual players make up the majority of the player base, yet their opinions get ignored. Most feedback from top players is based on what benefits their gameplay experience. Then they get destroyed by even better players, and suddenly they’re on a fresh account ten minutes later, pretending they’re “learning the character.”

Marvel Rivals sounded like the kind of game Marvel fans have been waiting years for—a fast-paced hero shooter packed with iconic abilities, teamwork mechanics, and flashy visuals. Unfortunately, once the excitement fades, the reality sets in: this game feels like a sloppy, uninspired mash-up that never quite figures out what it wants to be, and it shows in almost every match.

The first major issue is balance—or more accurately, the complete lack of it. Some heroes are so absurdly overtuned that they dominate every single match, while others feel like they were slapped together at the last minute. The result is a meta where you see the same characters repeated constantly because picking anyone else is basically throwing. It turns every match into a repetitive loop rather than an exciting strategic experience.

The maps are another huge problem. They look pretty at first glance, but once you actually play them, you realize how poorly designed they really are. Sightlines are awkward, chokepoints feel forced, and spawns are wildly inconsistent. Half the match is spent running back from respawn because the layout favors spawn-camping way more than it should. It’s supposed to be a team-based shooter, not a marathon.

Then there’s the netcode, which feels like it was duct-taped together overnight. Lag spikes and rubber-banding are so common that you begin to question whether it’s your internet or the game itself. Hit registration is inconsistent to the point of comedy—you can land a perfectly lined-up ability only for it to phase right through an enemy who then deletes you instantly.

The progression system is another mess. Everything is locked behind either absurd grinding or predatory monetization. Skins cost way too much, hero unlocks feel artificially dragged out, and it’s painfully obvious that the game is designed to push players toward spending money instead of rewarding skill or time invested.

And despite being a Marvel game, the writing is shockingly bland. Voice lines get recycled constantly, characters barely interact in meaningful ways, and the overall presentation lacks the charm and personality you’d expect from such iconic heroes.

In the end, Marvel Rivals feels like a game built around hype rather than quality. It has potential, but right now it’s buried under balancing issues, technical problems, and uninspired design. Unless major improvements are made, it’s hard to recommend this to anyone but the most dedicated Marvel fans.

So, for full transparency the vast majority of my time is on console but its the same game there as it is here, so i felt like writing up a review. This game is fun, some of the most fun PVP ive experienced in a long time, HOWEVER... it is also the most toxic, overdramatic communities I have ever seen. It puts Mw2 comms to shame at times. Using voice comms in ranked feels like youre stepping into a minefield. That combined with the absolutely awful matchmaking that prioritizes engagement and player retention over skill comparison fuses together to make an experience that you want to have fun with but really struggle to do. 

There are bots in quickplay which is advertised as PVP only. These bots are only given to you on a loss which is obviously to keep you playing, keep your morale up, which contradicts the develeopers comments that the matchmaking is not based on engagement. Ranked does not function off of skill comparison and will consistently reward players with negative winrates, numerous losses, and thus boost them to higher ranks where they do not belong and create a system where higher skill players are held back by the aforementioned low-skill players. Devs would rather release 32 skins an hour than fix these issues. 

Smurfs, throwers and toxic members do not receive lenghty bans as that would damage player retention and less players means less money, something Netease has written up numerous internal documents for that explicitly state that enagement is their top priority above all else, correlating the claims of EOMM (engagement based matchmaking) and contradicting their recent claims that the matchmaking does not feature these things. 

All in all, I cant recommend it. Youll be manipulated by Netease to give money for skins, to fuel their terrible matchmaking and support their lack of enforcement over the abysmal toxic community
